transcript.title: PM 120/1966 - Awardr of V.C. to Warrant Officer Class 2 Kevin Arthur Wheatley for Gallantry in Vietnam
transcript.content:
P. M. No. 120/ 1966

Her Majesty The Queen has bestowed posthumously the award of theÂ Victoria Gross upon the late Warrant Officer Class 2 Kevin Arthur Wheatley.

Warrant Officer Wheatley, who came from Sydney, was a member ofÂ the Australian Army Training Team Viet Nam from February, 1965 untilÂ his death on 13th November, 1965.Â 

Warrant Officer Wheatley displayed magnificent courage inÂ attempting to rescue a wounded comrade, Warrant Officer R. J. SwantonÂ of Brisbane, in the face of an overwhelming Viet Gong force estimated at
more than a company.Â 

On 13th November, 1965, a Vietnamese Civil Irregular DefenceÂ Group Gompany commenced a search and destroy operation in the Tra BongÂ Valley, Quang Nhai Province. Warrant Officers Wheatley and Swanton
accompanied the force with the right-hand platoon. Warrant OfficerÂ Wheatley sent a radio message to the centre platoon to report contact withÂ Viet Gong elements. The Viet Gong resistance increased in strength
until finally W-, arrant Officer Wheatley asked for. assistance.

While the centre platoon was working towards the action area,Â Warrant Officer Wheatley reported that VWarrant Officer Swanton had beenÂ hit in the chest, and requested an air strike and an aircraft for the evacuation
of casualties.

Warrant Officer Wheatley refused to abandon his dying comradeÂ when the company was forced to retreat. Under heavy machine gun andÂ automatic rifle fire, he managed to half drag, half carry Warrant Officer
Swanton from the open rice paddies to a wooded area some 200Â yards away.

During this time he was assisted by Private Dinh Do, a member ofÂ the company who, when the Viet Gong were only some ten yards away, urgedÂ Warrant Officer VWheatley to leave his dying comrade. Again he refused,Â and was seen to pull the pins from two grenades and calmly await the VietÂ Gong holding one grenade in each hand. Shortly afterwards, two grenadeÂ explosions were heard, followed by several bursts of fire.

The two bodies were found at first light next morning after theÂ fighting had ceased, with Warrant Officer Wheatley lying beside WarrantÂ Officer Swanton. Both had died of gunshot wounds.

Warrant Off icer Wheatley showed outstanding heroism, determinationÂ and unflinching devotion to a wounded comrade in the face of imminentÂ threat to his own life. His example takes a place of pride in the story of
Australia's fighting men.

CANBERRA,
14th December, 1966.Â 

The Prime Minister today sent the following telegram to theÂ late Warrant Officer Wheatley's widow:Â 

"On behalf of the Commonwealth Government, myÂ colleagues and I offer you our most sincere commendation ofÂ the award of the Victoria Cross bestowed by Her Majesty TheÂ Queen upon your late husband. His heroism and unflinchingÂ devotion to a wounded comrade should be a source of inspirationÂ and pride to all Australians."

BACKGROUND

Warrant Officer Wheatley, who was born on the 13th March,Â 1937, enlisted in the Regular Army in 1956. He served in Malaya withÂ the 3rd Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment from 1957 to 1959 andÂ then with the 2nd and 1st Battalions of the Regiment until February, 1965,Â when he was posted to the Australian Army Training Team Viet Nam.Â Warrant Officer Wheatley's posting in this area had been distinguished by
meritorious and gallant service.

Warrant Officer Wheatley's award is the 93rd V. C. awarded toÂ an Australian and the first since World War 11.

The last award was made on 22nd January, 1946, to the lateÂ Private Frank John Partridge for action at Bougainville on 24th July, 1945
